image.altText: A disability facility in suburban Adelaide.

props.synopsis: A South Australian government aged care home, which looks after 23 people with dementia or complex disabilities, inappropriately used lap belts and other mechanical restraints to stop falls and control residents' behaviour, the ABC can reveal.

title.children: 'It's a human rights tragedy': Aged care facility inappropriately restrained residents

image.altText: Shaun de Bruyn stands in a grassed area wearing a white shirt and navy suit

props.synopsis: Tourism, seafood industry and community representatives are calling for greater funding, education and travel incentives ahead of the release of the South Australian government's upcoming Summer Plan.

title.children: Tourism operators facing 'dire straits' without more algal bloom relief

image.altText: A couple of people riding waves on surfboards.

props.synopsis: A surfer has gone to hospital after being twice bitten by a shark who was reportedly chasing a seal in waters off Kangaroo Island.

title.children: Surfer bitten twice by shark chasing seal off Kangaroo Island

image.altText: A building with grey, green and brown colouring and the words 'Edge Early Learning'

props.synopsis: The Education Standards Board has closed Edge Early Learning Centre at Plympton for 90 days following an investigation into reports of "inadequate supervision" of children.Â

title.children: SA childcare centre 'unsuitable to open' amid supervision concerns

image.altText: Flames at the blast furnace at Whyalla's steelworks.

props.synopsis: A future made in Australia? Not if gas prices keep rising, major manufacturers warn as they call for urgent action to secure affordable supply.

title.children: Industry warns 'no gas, no future' amid high prices and falling demand

image.altText: A headshot of Taylor Swift with jewels and feathers surrounding her head

props.synopsis: Founder and designer Paul Vasileff says he's grateful to have his Adelaide-made couture dress on the world stage with pop superstar Taylor Swift wearing it in the new The Fate of Ophelia music video.

title.children: Taylor Swift wears Adelaide label Paolo Sebastian in new music video

image.altText: John Noh speaks into a microphone at a wood desk.

props.synopsis: The AUKUS submarine pact may need "commonsense" action from both Australia and the US to make it more "sustainable", according to Donald Trump's nominee to oversee US defence strategy in the Indo-Pacific.

title.children: Trump's Pentagon nominee flags possible 'commonsense' AUKUS changes

image.altText: Photo of Gus

props.synopsis: Police say they have conducted a "significant" aerial search of a property in South Australia's mid-north, where a four-year-old boy went missing 10 days ago.

title.children: Results of drone searches for 4yo Gus on SA property 'being analysed'

image.altText: A male police officer looking into the distance.

props.synopsis: South Australia's corruption watchdog has cleared Police Commissioner Grant Stevens of a discipline breach for accidentally discharging his firearm during a house raid in the early 1990s.

title.children: SA Police Commissioner cleared over 1990s firearm incident

image.altText: A bunch of healthy looking tomatoes on a vine.

props.synopsis: More than a year since South Australia's $230 million tomato and capsicum sector was plunged into turmoil by the first discovery of the tomato brown rugose fruit virus in Australia, the state has been declared free of the exotic disease.

title.children: Relief for fruit producers as SA declared free from brown rugose virus

image.altText: A white sign with two logos and writing on it with a road, a blue sky and bushland behind it.

props.synopsis: The corporation has been fined $2,000 for failing to lodge reports to the Office of the Registrar of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Corporations.

title.children: Indigenous-run corporation convicted, fined for failing to lodge reports

image.altText: A smaller Kangaroo stands in front of a larger kangaroo in high grass.

props.synopsis: Farmers are calling for a cull of kangaroos, which they say are being forced onto farmland by drought and dry conditions and consuming what little feed and water they have.Â

title.children: Kangaroos add pressure on drought-hit farmers by eating scarce feed

image.altText: An empty potato shelf at Woolworths in South Australia.

props.synopsis: South Australia produces 80 per cent of Australia's fresh potatoes, but extreme weather and drought across the state are causing a major shortage.Â

title.children: Customers face empty shelves as farmers battle potato shortage

image.altText: Two teenage Indigenous boys fishing in the Darling River at Wilcannia, with a man in a blue shirt watching on.

props.synopsis: After decades of lobbying and design controversy, the New South Wales government says it needs another $30â40 million to proceed with the Wilcannia Weir upgrade.

title.children: Outback water project unlikely due to $30m shortfall, minister says

image.altText: A vast waterway from above

props.synopsis:
The floodwaters which have created an expansive inland oasis on the usually arid salt beds of Kati Thanda-Lake Eyre have reached a peak, and are beginning to evaporate, a local pilot says.

Â

title.children: Floodwaters 'transform whole desert' as Kati Thanda-Lake Eyre reaches peak

image.altText: Charlie Kirk is stood with a microphone in one hand and a red cap in the other.

props.synopsis: The Australian affiliate of late right-wing activist Charlie Kirk's Turning Point USA is moving into South Australia ahead of next year's state election, but some politicians say the group is "out of step with mainstream values".

title.children: Turning Point Australia moves into SA, ahead of state election

image.altText: A close up image of an SA Police car.

props.synopsis: A Port Pirie woman has been bailed after police downgraded a murder charge laid over the death of a man to aggravated assault.

title.children: Woman's murder charge downgraded over Port Pirie death

image.altText: A red sign on a bus shelter reading Buy the Best, Buy SA Seafood

props.synopsis: While industry and government tell consumers South Australian seafood is safe, consumer demand is still down amid the algal bloom, with businesses concerned they may not survive.

title.children: Seafood 'good as it's ever been' as sellers fear algal bloom message not getting through

image.altText: Masooma smiles at the camera.

props.synopsis: Masooma came to Adelaide as a refugee from Afghanistan in 2016, and has become the carer of a young girl from a similar cultural background. Experts say it is important carers reflected the diversity of children in care.

title.children: For Afghan refugee Masooma, fostering a child has given her a sense of freedom

image.altText: A white woman with long brown hair and glasses standing in a kitchen

props.synopsis: A year after a controversial NDIS change, advocates are growing increasingly concerned that "counterintuitive" and "nonsensical" funding decisions are reducing participant independence.

title.children: 'I was so cross': NDIS participants blast 'nonsensical' spending rules

image.altText: A woman in police uniform at a press conference.

props.synopsis: In a wide-ranging interview as she begins as AFP commissioner, Krissy Barrett announces a new sub-terror strike force, and flags that newly written hate crime laws may need to be strengthened further.

title.children: New AFP boss warns hate crime laws may need to be strengthened further

image.altText: A woman in a dark hijab smiles as she holds a toddler in her arms on a beach.

props.synopsis: Children in Gaza are experiencing grief, loss, displacement, and starvation. For some, this is all they know or remember.

title.children: 'He doesn't feel like a normal child': War's toll on Gaza's babies

image.altText: Anika Wells leafs through papers in the House of Representatives.

props.synopsis: The adequacy of Australia's emergency call network will be stress tested with a surprise drill ahead of bushfire season, as the opposition ramps up its assault over the communication minister's handling of last month's fatal triple-0 outage.

title.children: Telcos face surprise 'stress test' within weeks as Optus fallout continues

image.altText: blue Optus signage outside an office on Lyonmark Road

props.synopsis: The communications department did not find out about the Optus outage for more than a day after it occurred because an email was sent to the wrong address, Senate estimates has heard. Follow live.

title.children: Email detailing Optus triple-0 outage sent to wrong government mailbox

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Optus sent email about outage to the wrong address

Communications Department lashes Optus over outage

image.altText: Donald Trump sits in a blue suit and white shirt speaking to someone out of frame.

props.synopsis: US President Donald Trump has made no secret that he wants to win this year's Nobel Peace Prize. Here's why experts say it's unlikely he'll win the prestigious award.

title.children: Will Trump win the Nobel Peace Prize?

image.altText: Brandon Starcevich stands for a photo wearing his Lions kit and holding two premiership cups

props.synopsis: The first big deal of the AFL trade period is set to go through, and it could be the catalyst for a number of other massive moves. Follow live.

title.children: Premiership Lion part of four-club mega-deal set to ignite AFL trade period

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Sam Flanders is soon to move. Is Christian Petracca next?
Brandon Starcevich set for West Coast in multi-club deal

image.altText: A saltwater crocodile leaning up against a muddy brown bank, with black zip-ties around it's mouth.

props.synopsis: The discovery of a saltwater crocodile with its mouth bound shut by zip ties in a Darwin river has sparked outrage, with animal rights advocates calling for stronger wildlife protections.

title.children: Disturbing discovery of zip-tied crocodile triggers investigation

image.altText: Mobile phone betting apps generic

props.synopsis: The NT government is standing by its de-facto regulation of Australiaâs $50 billion online gambling industry, despite allegations that it is too closely linked to the sector.

title.children: Calls for national gambling watchdog grow after NT regulator accusations

image.altText: a man in a yellow jumper looking at rubble

props.synopsis:
Residents who lost their homes in a blaze that ripped through WA's southern wheatbelt in January may have to wait more than two years to seek compensation.

Â

title.children: Widower living in bus as he waits for answers on fire that destroyed home

image.altText: A concept image of the proposed Hobart stadium at Macquarie Poi nt.

props.synopsis: The state government response to last month's scathing report from the planning commission says that while "change can be challenging", the "dream of a Tasmanian team representing our state in the AFL and AFLW is now within reach â we cannot turn back".

title.children: 'Cannot turn back': Tasmanian government responds to scathing Hobart stadium report

image.altText: Woman wearing a camera strapped to her

props.synopsis: A Queensland council is ramping up efforts to protect staff following an alarming rise in verbal and physical abuse.

title.children: Council resorts to security guards, body cameras amid rising violence

image.altText: Close-up of a black stingless bee sitting on a white flower petal of an orchid.

props.synopsis: Researchers behind a new study examining thousands of flower specimens collected over the past century say temperature increases could be behind a pollination decline in native orchids.

title.children: One hundred years of Australian flower data reveals pollination drop
